cons: Though I feel it is reversible, Yahoo was on a decline before the economy turned sour - and with two rounds of layoffs in under a year, it's had the effect of shoving a lot of good people out the door before they get caught unawares. That's created an above average level of churn, which really cuts out a lot of momentum towards changes.I also think Yahoo! can be a bit hidebound at times, depending on the mana… gement above you. Sometimes shipping a lite version is better market insight than a market study.
advice: Yahoo's got good bones, and passionate people - but we need to quickly (<1 year) get to a few key initiatives and start getting clear wins. Don't sell Search - the insights are too valuable to so many other products.
pros: There are not a lot of companies out there where just about any new product gets 50+ PR mentions and thousands of users on Day 1 of its release. That's just the coolest thing in the world. And I love the challenge of coming up with pretty broadly appealing mass market products - how am I going to make something that works for at least half the Internet?
summary: Despite choppy waters at the moment, I really enjoy working here now and look forward to winning the challenges ahead.

cons: You have to develop thick skin as media has been lashing out at the company for a long time.Matrix org structure makes it difficult to figure out responsible groups. Success has many fathers and failures have none. Too many managers and incompetent sales force.
advice: Get out of the shadow of Google. Yahoo! is still a great company with many great people. Improve decision making. Get rid of dead wood.
pros: - "Yahoo!" brand on your resume: Contrary to what many so called financial analysts of bankrupt Lehman Brothers, Merill Lynch, Goldman Sachs etc. describe; the company still carries a great reputation among general public.- So many really smart people: Some of the people are really top notch. A look at the developer network would give you a glimpse of the talent at Yahoo!- Fun culture: People work hard and pa… rty harder- Free latte/mocha and other facilities: Great facilities. Although, no 'free food' but good pay. Free lattes alone can save you $1200 every year. :-POverall, a great environment to work

cons: bad management - hire too much then fire. they also hire senior level management that doesn't have experience and definitely does not have experience in the area, so the team fails. over spending is also a huge issue - they have great parties but should have cut back. the overtime that some people did was crazy!!!!
advice: convert the good contractors and get rid of the employees that don't do anything
pros: it's just a fun place to work - i found my best friends at yahoo and loved going into work but i think the environment is a bit too relaxed for the competition and the market out there right now. At least your opinions were heard and you got a lot of freedom to build your own programs.
summary: fun place to work with great people but bad management

cons: In general, there have been too many product lines with little integration effort to draw synergies. As a result, there could be a lack of focus in terms of market position to offer an attractive value proposition to end users. The future direction and vision are not clear in recent years, especially with the frequent change of upper management.
advice: Define the near and long term strategies to compete ASAP
pros: Managers are in general opened for opinions. Yahoo! has a strong culture for having fun at work and the management has a strong commitment to talents. Innovation is part of the culture as well. There are a lot of industry experts and early pioneers in the company.

cons: Too many managers. People getting comfortable and not pushing their limits. Too many meetings. Too many emails
advice: There are too many manager. Give engineers your confidence and let them do their work, minus the unnecessary reports / meetings
pros: With some luck, it's possible to advance through the hierarchy of job positions in a company of this size
summary: Overall still a great place to work

cons: Company is lack of direction overall. Heavy middle management and lack of responsibilities of individual and team. Innovation and hardworking doesn't get rewarded as they used to be
advice: focus
pros: Good for work and life balance. Flexible working hours and generally nice people. Good perk and benefit, informal and easy going environment

cons: Lot of Silos and not focused on one thing. There are projects which needs more structure and some of special interests needs to be managed properly. I think Yahoo needs more guidance for engineers and less management interference.
advice: Yahoo need to make sure some middle management people are very political in nature and need to get rid of those politics for engineer to strive
pros: Lot of Energetic people around and there are very smart people and top management is some what too thrifty about some real needs of company. One thing I hate is hardware selection of the company where only cost matters rather than total cost of ownership.

cons: It is still a young company that grew fast. There is a lot of disorganization and duplication of effort internally.
advice: Once you sort things out organizationally I think its important to foster more ownership in the management. Management is always moving around too much and too fast.
pros: It really is a great place to work despite all the flack Yahoo! gets. I truly enjoyed my time at Yahoo!

cons: Not very stable, too much reorg, company is not going the right direction, working too hard, not good stock price.
advice: There are too many managers, and so too many layers and less efficient. As a result, many first line managers' are not technically strong enough.
pros: It has fair compensation, I can work on interesting project. Good employee training system. More opportunity to play a role in project.

cons: Upper Management is still acting as if Yahoo! is still a garage start-up; middle Management is more concerned with the political infighting than supporting the troops in the trenches. Politics getting in the way of Progress....
advice: Flatten the structure, get rid of the assorted VP's and Executive VP's. Decide on where the Company is going to be in five years and go for it. Quit reacting to Wall Street and listen to your User base.
pros: Good folks to work with, interesting problems to work on. You have a chance to make an enormous impact on a large number of people. Yahoo! defines the term 'Internet Scale'.

cons: It's a big company that is stuck with many acquisitions, and along with that, many different platforms for running the site. Everyone has their own way of doing things and usually they don't want to accept other ways. They need to standardize on one thing, not ten.
advice: Pay attention to your employees ideas and the market. I felt like the upper management did not pay attention to the very brilliant people working there or the direction of the market (besides what wall street thought).
pros: Yahoo is a great place to work. They understand work life balance. They treat employees as humans, not resources. Overall its definitely the best place I've ever worked at.

cons: - Morale is generally not great because of attrition and layoffs and Yahoo! is getting beaten up in the press- Management is always shuffling around and there are alot of political turf wars- Consensus driven (impossible to make a quick decision and move quickly). For a Product Manager this is especially frustrating and undermining.
advice: Focus on product excellence and delighting consumers. Depoliticize the management team.
pros: - You're surrounded of talented and creative and cool employees.- The work, despite the occasional distractions and annoyances, the work is still satisfying- You'll keep on top of the latest and greatest web and consumer internet design- Nice environment (if you're on the Sunnyvale Campus... not so great on the other campuses like Santa Clara)
summary: A good place to work if you can find the right position.

cons: Poor leaderships, bad HR people and inexperience employees. These make it hard to request for service or to change direction. Too much complications and meetings.
advice: Streamline the process and focus back to Engineering. Let HR know that their role is to help employee to be successful.
pros: A lot of smart people whom are expert in their respective fields. Very collegiate, fun, and friendly atmosphere work environment.Opportunities to do research and tech advancement.
summary: Smart People, bad management and HR

cons: Some problems are well known: Yahoo! lacked a clear vision from upon high. There were intergroup rivalries; your world may have been reproduced by someone at some other location, and they would try to undercut you in favor of their own group. Planning was weak; many deadlines were missed, largely because people had not properly calculated the resources that were needed. The last year I was there, my group realized th… ey had not planned adequately in the past, and overcompensated by insisting on a rather bureaucratic process which killed off much of our group's innovation.I don't think this was a widespread problem in Yahoo!, but in my specific situation I dealt with a couple managers who came off as particularly manipulative. I didn't form friendships of the sort I had at other employers; there was a bit of a revolving door.
advice: it's a hard to know what to do with it. Handing search and search advertizing to Microsoft may have been a huge mistake, but time will tell.
pros: Frankly, I took a lot of pride at the opportunity to work on technology that got used by so many people. I learned an awful lot about what it takes to keep a web site reliable. At its best, it encouraged the creativity of its engineers and designers. They were very concerned about the feedback they got from customers; I felt I really knew what the public thought of our technology and what we needed to do to improve i… t. The competence level of engineers and designers was high. A couple years back, it felt as if what we did was really going to change the world.Yahoo! had a constant flow of fun events and interesting presentations by knowledgible speakers. They treated us well. The facilities - with the fitness centers and cafeterias - were great. I got the opportunity to travel overseas a couple times, which broadened my view of the world.
summary: Fun place to work that lost its buzz

cons: Jerry and Sue were the wrong people to lead the company. That's fixed now, and friends there seem much more optimistic.Decision making was awful. Generally unclear who made the decision, and thus 4 people tried to make it and nobody followed anything.Matrix organization gave too much power to Product Mgmt. Engineering had no budget, but had to "work with" (read beg) product for any headcount needed. Hard to g… et people staffed on maintenance and code cleanup/repair (technical debt) projects.
advice: Be better than the old management. Make quick decisions and make them stick. Balance the responsibility between Eng and PM.
pros: One of the centers of the internet world Was THE center in 1998.Lots of groups to work in, pretty good freedom to move aroundGood growth opportunity in Engineering
summary: Management was bad in 2008, curious to see how it performs now

cons: 1. unstable org/ too much restructuring/ layoffs2. lacks strategy for financial growth/ dealing with competition
advice: Come out with a strategy to achieve financial growth
pros: 1.cutting-edge work/ professional growth2.work life balance
summary: Good place to be but uncertain future

cons: Yahoo! is often spoken of in the shadow of Google - even though Yahoo! is a prime Internet portal. Also, management is not always transparent, for e.g., with the recent Microsoft-yahoo deal.
advice: Talk to your soldiers: i.e., the engineers before making big-time mergers/deals. It is insufficient to simply loop in upper management.
pros: Well know brand, strong impact on mainstream media. Extremely smart engineering team, and very ethnically diverse. Higher than average compensation.

cons: things have been so muddled for so long that it will take 2-3 years to cut away the fat to get to where yahoo needs to be in terms of systems, operations, product development, and processes
advice: get a focus and exexute
pros: great place to work, especially if you have kids, they recognize that you have a life outside of yahoo

cons: There are many layers of management and different properties (mail, front page, news, search, etc.) don't necessarily work with each other. If you join one property you'll effectively be working for that silo-ed division of the company. Change comes slowly and only after layers of management have reviewed the change.
advice: Create incentives for different parts of the company (different properties) to work with each other.
pros: Yahoo has a very open culture. The benefits are great and compensation is very good. There are very smart people and a collaborative, competitive culture. Food is subsidized and coffee is free. The campus is fun; and they encourage employees to have a good work/life balance.
summary: Great place to work for designers

cons: Lack of innovation, lack of transparency, lack of focus, plenty of slackers, engineers have little significance in decision making, and layers of middle management.
advice: Cut the fat. Pressure managers to deliver more. Focus on improving core properties in innovative ways. Keep improving user's experience in any way possible.
pros: Huge impact, great people to work with, fun culture, great compensation & benefits package, free coffee, good work-life balance, and lots of opportunities to learn.
summary: Increasingly becoming a sales and marketing shop

cons: This is a great place to work but I am sure everyone is aware of all the problems Yahoo has been having recently so chances of going through a layoff is higher at Yahoo compared to competitors.
advice: I have no advice for the management at this moment but I have to fill this space so all I'll say is keep your focus on what you've been focusing on. It is better to focus on the wrong target than to have no focus at all.
pros: Yahoo is a good place to work if you can channel out all the negative stuff surrounding the company and just focus on your work, enjoy the great benefits and the really relaxed and laid back working environment.

cons: - incredibly bureaucratic. getting access to databases, systems and processes takes forever- the organization structure is a mess. people have indirect reports left and right. positions are vague. you never quite know what someone is doing within the organization.
advice: Streamline processes within the company. Flatten the organization. Also, change the marketing tactics. Instead of pure brand messaging on prime-time, also have product-specific ads with common themes. Different products have different audiences...
pros: - people understand how to balance work and life. they work hard but also leave at 5pm to be with their families- great people. after the recent lay-offs, those left behind appear to be very intelligent and hard-working, as well as great to work with- it's still a great company with an incredible brand and products that touch millions of people
summary: People take their jobs seriously but still have a life

cons: There is no clear vision from corporate executives.Company is running like a start-up company but lack of start-up's efficiency.Too many management levels and non-productive employees.
advice: Clear vision for the company is badly needed.Prioritize projects inside the company; cut low priority projects, and invest on key projects/products.Improve management efficiency.
pros: Compensation is fair. Flexible working hours. Plenty of opportunity to learn, either through various projects or training. Work and life balance in general is good.
summary: No Vision. Organization is a mess

cons: Indecisive management, amateur politics, cylos, engineers are supreme; management doesn't understand/value other professions besides engineering.
advice: Yahoo doesn't have a uniform culture. My advise to any interviewee is to assess each group you interview with rather than making a decision based on your impression of Yahoo as a whole.
pros: Energetic, passionate peopleLatest technologies to work with

cons: Depending on your manager and group, you may or may not like it and feel like you are on your own. Some people are used to being told what to do at all times, some dont.
advice: I do not have any input with regards to management as I had to work for many managers at the time.
pros: Cutting edge technology, good environment, nice people, good perks, life/work balance, food, shuttle, bonuses, good reputation and good thing to put in your resume.

cons: Getting rid of the search team, I'm not so sure about. Yahoo wants to become a smaller company. Will their technical leadership stick around?
advice: I don't know what Yahoo leadership is doing. Selling off search may be a smart business decision on it's own, but do they realize that all the talent (search team or not) is leaving with them?
pros: Yahoo is (was) a great company. The work environment is good, the people are smart, and there's opportunity for high impact. Also, you get good perks, benefits, and a competitive salary.

cons: - Constant rumors of layoffs- Not bringing innovative products to market- Feeling of stagnation- Exec shuffles never end
advice: - Stop the incessant re-orgs- Hire senior management in the location were the team actually resides- Start innovating
pros: - Flexible hours if need be. You can really manage your own schedule and people do respect it, or stay quiet about.- Cross-functional teams are mostly beneficial to everyone involved.
summary: Been with Yahoo! with more than 3 years and will plan on staying there for a while (if i end up surviving post MSFT)

cons: being compared to google.i just want to say. if you want to be a real code monkey, working in inane problems that no one else sees. work for google.
advice: be more transparent about management and strategy decisions. we trust you, but we want to know where this is headed.
pros: y! is different. its a content company. it started as one, and always, in its heart, it will be about serving interesting and useful content.as a developer, its an interesting place to be. you are on the front-lines, you see the business and processes, and you deal with the best and proven web technologies out there.you learn a lot, the pay is competitive, and the work-life balance is great.th… e best thing about yahoo is that you work at a company that caters to the masses: i went into the company being a hardcore code monkey, and came out with an appreciation for the common internet surfer. really opened my eyes to the opportunities of enabling others to use the web.
summary: great place - for engineers with a soul

cons: Innovation not happening everywhereSome managers are not good
advice: Hire better managers, let go the othersDecisions should be made fasterMost people have no idea where Yahoo! is going and they don't seem to care
pros: Most people love Yahoo!Pretty good salary

cons: - Low morale in search and advertising groups- Sometimes senior management lacks in providing direction- Too many reorgs
advice: - Yahoo can still get its glory back, but please set up the environment which is conduicive. Too many reorgs cause a lot of confusion between engineers and PMs working on projects.- Encourage the culture to take risks. We seem to have lost it over last couple of years.
pros: - Good salary- Good perks- Friendly and intelligent coworkers- Very open, executives very approachable and ready to listen
summary: Great place to work, Good perks, Sometimes lacking direction

cons: Management seems impotent to capitalize on Yahoo's talent. Constant reorgs keep you from being unable to get anything done. Ineffectual upper management tends to trickle down to lower management.
advice: Stop with all the reorgs and stick with one strategy and see it through to completion. Panama was a failure, APT has been a failure, and now just as the search technology is getting really good, we undermine ourselves with the Bing deal.
pros: Great benefits. The shuttle saves me a ton of cash. You'll be hard pressed to find more subject area experts in the spaces that Yahoo competes in.
summary: Great environment, great perks and benefits, bad execution of strategy.

cons: Constant management turmoil which has probably abated somewhat now the Carol Bartz appears to be firmly in command. Stock just won't move so don't expect those options to be worth much for a while.
advice: Goaling was often done after the quarter had already started which allowed Yahoo to keep people from making too much money in case you did hit a home run.
pros: Biggest player in the display space which gains you lots of access. Usually the biggest share of anybody's budget in the portal space. REALLY big dollars, no scrounging for pennies here. Lot's of new technologies to present.

cons: Obviously, Yahoo is having a tough time increasing it's revenue. While other Internet companies are growing, Yahoo is struggling to grow. It's revenue is heavily dependent on display advertising which was hit hard ever since the economy began a recession around 2008. The hostile takeover attempt by Microsoft also created divisions within the company and many talented employees left as a result .Prior to 2008,…  I became frustrated that Yahoo wasn't aggressive in seeking new growth opportunities. (In particular, I always wondered where was Yahoo's version of AdSense. It exists today, but is not competitive.) I wanted Yahoo to kick ass. I wanted to be part of a winning team. But in the end, I felt like I was playing for a 2nd or 3rd place team. In Silicon Valley, if you're a decent software engineer it's not difficult to find a new job. Thus I decided to move on from Yahoo.
advice: Aggressively seek out new markets. Expand and don't focus on contracting (layoffs). Growth is the way to succeed. Rely less on advertising as a source of revenue. Maybe acquire some of the cool web hosting companies like Weebly, Square Space, etc. Or look into cloud computing as a new business. Just make sure that paid services surpasses advertising as the main source of revenue.
pros: My overall experience at Yahoo was positive. The company treats employees well by giving them competitive salaries, decent benefits, some nice perks like a gym, and a fun year end party. People at Yahoo are friendly, open minded, and willing to help each other.As software engineer, I learned some good programming practices related to code modularity, scalability, and maintainability. The scale at which Yahoo … operates is very large (still one of the biggest websites in the world) and that means there are cool problems to solve (i.e. what is a good data store for holding 500 million user accounts? Make it fast, reliable, and secure). There are also regular tech talks, which can be stimulating.
summary: Nice place to work, but I wanted the company to be more successful.

cons: Upper management seems weak. They don't interact directly with us pawns, and they don't set much of an example. The company mission statement, "Yahoo! powers and delights our communities of users, advertisers, and publishers – all of us united in creating indispensable experiences, and fueled by trust.', is exemplary of the problem.
advice: Quit.
pros: Friendly people, low-stress environment, huge scale systems that reach a lot of users, and many brilliant coworkers.
summary: Great place to work, could use more technical rock stars

cons: - Command-and-control management- Exodus of key personnel- 2-paragraph mission statement- Severe burnout: Need to hire more producers
advice: Let people innovate. Reward experimentation. Stop doing the same things over and over and expecting a better/different outcome. Stop trying to be other companies. Leverage your brand better.
pros: - 500 million users- Brand recognition- Opportunities to do different things- A big player in the Internet world- In the heart of Silicon Valley

cons: Senior management always changing, and does not seem to know where they are headed.
advice: Needs to stick to a plan.
pros: Treats employees really well.Money and benefits are really good.Learn from one of the most trafficked sites in the world.
summary: Great place to work if you are starting to build a career.

cons: Fairly large org so it can be hard to feel like you've made a meaningful difference to the bottom line.
advice: Yahoo should continue to cut non-core businesses and focus on doing fewer things great!Improve your mobile content and advertising products along with your local information services.
pros: Ability to reach millions of users.High quality peers and personal networking.Fun, creative environment.Decent work and life balance.

cons: Low share value, as good as peanuts. A mix of media and technology, so to say not totally technology company.
advice: Provide more incentives to the employees. Regular incentives and surprise incentives go a long way in getting good results from the employees.
pros: Good environment, good people, good facilities, good pay, flexilibility, Variety of technical groups and good scope of growh too is there.

cons: long hoursself-imposed deadlinesmediocre medical benefitsparties to celebrate every release (got tiring)
advice: Pay heed to the joke about the big search companies: Google is run by engineers, Microsoft is run by lawyers, and Yahoo! is run by Hollywood types. Too true and likely to be Yahoo's ruin in the long run. Sorry Jerry & Filo....it was a good run.while it lasted.
pros: 100 smartest people on the internet back then were the first 100 yahoosopen communication from upper managementparties to celebrate every releasevideo game centerEntertainment People (company band!)
summary: Early days were great - dunno about now (worked there 1996/7)

cons: Some teams are territorial and do not like to cooperate for the bigger picture. Sometimes work creeps into your entire life, taking phone calls, checking/responding to emails all times of the day and night
advice: Try to stay ahead of the curve. There are times when it seems that Yahoo is trying to catch up or dropped the ball on key projects
pros: Interesting projects, get to work with great teams and individuals, scale and breath of your projects enable you to touch almost 1 out 10 people in the world.

cons: there can be many long hours of extra time to met project deadlinescompany still has not yet found its way
advice: Yahoo is a great company to work for but still has not yet found its way. There's stil a ton of talent at the company but we need stronger management and direction to really succeed
pros: great work environmentwork with very talented and fun peopleget to work with new cutting edge technologiescompensation is very competitive
summary: Great environment to learn and grow professionally

cons: - development resources were always the bottleneck.- felt like we never shipped new products- didn't always have a clear picture of priorities
advice: spend more time with your team. you need to learn about each member and figure out their strengths and weaknesses
pros: - people are great to work with- learned a lot from my colleagues- fun environment - interesting content
summary: Was great place to work - years ago

cons: The work was not particularly interesting. Most of it was maintenance coding.
advice: None
pros: Yahoo was a very good place to work. It provided a very good work/life balance, and the people were very smart and nice; no real egos to deal with. The facilities were great, and the food was pretty good.

cons: Low BonusAverage SalariesLack of strategic focus
advice: Streamline operationsFocus on a few priorities - do not try to be jack of all trades
pros: Excellent CultureGreat LearningGood work life balanceGood On site facilities

cons: - Too much of the maintenance-oriented- Ideas don't go quickly, which leads to not much of engineering innovation
advice: Move quickly and don't make it to be maintenance company. Get the engineers to get cool ideas for every release!
pros: - There are still a lot of areas that could be improved, a place to make difference!- Flexible work time- A lot of smart people, friendly, and helpful- Perks are extra credits
summary: A lot of opportunity for growth and make difference!

cons: The direction of the company has not been clear. Several leadership groups came and went while I was with the company, and all sounded roughly the same, though all claimed to have a much clearer vision. Carol as an individual has made a impact on the organization, but it's not clear that she can turn it all around. There is a culture of playing-it-safe that needs to be uprooted.
advice: Keep trimming, keep investing in the things that the company is successful at and where there is growth to be had. Don't be afraid to admit a bad bet and cut your losses.
pros: Great benefits package, fun atmosphere (even if it feels a bit forced at times), flexible management, relatively open for a company its size - there's plenty of opportunities to suggest ideas to upper management and to be recognized.
summary: Sputtering, but still a great place to work

cons: Yahoo has missed on several key industry changes and it is losing relevance with consumers and advertisers so employees are scrambling. Senior management needs an overhaul.
advice: Reset financial goals and focus on the consumer again. Collaboration is great, but decision making is way too complicated and slow. Streamline and focus!
pros: Yahoo is a good company to work for. Pay and benefits are good, employees are smart and there are lots of passionate people eager to contribute.

cons: organization structures that initiate projects and product development.
advice: Need to clarify the product directions
pros: flexible time, interesting projects, good benefits, gym facility, etc

cons: Outsiders think that Yahoo has missed on several opportunities and is having a hard time to keep eyeballs on several properties. Senior management changes have been going on for a while, with several reorgs.
advice: Listen more to lower-level employees (engineers, implementers) and solicit their feedback. Identify which projects are 'pet projects' and which are useful.
pros: Very good company to work for. Employees are above average and you will find good people who work hard and contribute. Pay and benefits are good too.

cons: Long commute for meSometimes difficult to move up in the same org.

pros: Lots of interesting projects to work on. Lots of smart people to work with. Lots of in-house libraries to learn from. One of the few places in the world to learn how to build a web-scale platform.
summary: Great place to work on web-scale technologies.

cons: Sometimes a passive aggressive culture. People could be a little more proactive in either agreeing or disagreeing to do something. Atleast then once you know people agree, you have faith they will follow through.
advice: better alignment to actually achieve a goal. Stick with the same org until you acheive the goal. Too much disruption can cause the company to keep spinning.
pros: Great place to work, embraces diversity, open culture, very cognizant of work/family life balance, truly flexible, work hard & play hard is the motto. High end technology & a fun place to be.

cons: Keep faith in new projects, adaptaion
advice: Keep Improving
pros: Superb HR, Employees Care, Strong culture

cons: The few leads that would come in went managers "friends", no plan on how to grow book of business, no direction from mamagement when asked for help re: prospecting, customer questions, product changes, product issues, etc.
advice: None...Yahoo sold HotJobs to Monster
pros: Office location, awesome work environment, work hard, play hard mentality, Yahoo's benefits, fun co-workers all around the same age, company happy hours/outings/sporting events, great random office bonuses

cons: Big company equals over process sometimes. Takes a long time to get anything done. Diverse people work at different pace so fast pace people may get frustrated with others.
advice: Work on innovation more than anything else. Innovation helps the company grow and "reinvent" itself. Stick with the same thing day in and day out and eventually, the company becomes a dinosaur.
pros: Balance between work and personal life. Big company with lots of bright people. Fun events and perks makes working here fun.

cons: Seems the senior management has forgotten what an internet company should do. They need to be more innovative, or at least maintain a department that innovates. Regardless of whether Yahoo becomes a media company or what, it needs to truly encourage the thinkers here to really think way out of the box. We did have some outstanding engineers here, but with Search gone, there is really no cutting edge technology that c… an differentiate Yahoo from another web portal. In the Valley, once you stop innovating, you stop the growth needed to stay a power on the Web and you stop attracting the people that will make a difference for the future.
advice: Stop the brain drain, if at all possible. If you're going to buy a property, don't let it die after purchasing it. it's a waste of lots of money and talent. Plus, it is demoralizing to the people that are still here. We need inspiration from Senior management.
pros: People here are very intelligent. I've met some amazing individuals that truly inspire the people around them. Access to job related training is good. Work environment is good. And the all you can drink coffee bar is outstanding!!
summary: Yahoo, not as bad as you might think

cons: - Transparency- Need to be more agile
advice: - People need to be held accountable- Need more transparency in feeback and review
pros: - Chance to work with really talented and highly motivated people- Technology stack is good- Problems faced are challenging

cons: At Yahoo, there were too many reorganizations to caused lots of distractions instead a focus on the projects. A Microsoft buyout was not healthy for the organization
advice: Focus more on the internal workings of the company and less on the stock price and then the products will end up speaking for themselves.
pros: Overall, I worked with some great product teams at Yahoo. Great product managers and technical leads made for some very satisfying job experience.

cons: No advancement opportunities and job satisfaction.
advice: Higher pay to employees.
pros: Fun and place to work

cons: - Need to establish it's own identity- Not understanding it's core strength- Getting confused amidst various competing products
advice: - Understand your strength and reason why users come to Yahoo! every day- Provide the best user experience in the world
pros: - Respect for employees- Freedom to champion your ideas- Community environment- Balance between work and personal life
summary: Yahoo! is still great place to work

cons: Big company structure so things are slow. The organizational structure is clearly not optimal although changing quiet a lot lately (hopefully for the better).The company has some difficulties right now but has some good opportunities as well.
